summary:

recently by Kowalski and Rembieli\'nski [J. Phys. A 35 (2002) 1405] is not
consistent with the state localization. We argue that the relevant
uncertainties and uncertainty relations (UR's) on a circle are that based on
the Gram-Robertson matrix. Several of these generalized UR's are displayed and
related criterions for squeezed states are discussed.

Abstract
It is shown by examples that the position uncertainty on a circle, proposed recently by Kowalski
and Rembieliński [J. Phys. A 35 (2002) 1405] is not consistent with the state localization. We
argue that the relevant uncertainties and uncertainty relations (UR's) on a circle are that based on
the Gram-Robertson matrix. Several of these generalized UR's are displayed and related criterions
for squeezed states are discussed.

In order to define squeezed states on the circle let us recall that for the particle on the real line
these states are defined by means of one of the two inequalities (∆x)2 < |h[x, p]i|/2 = 1/2, or (∆p)2 <
|h[x, p]i|/2 = 1/2. Since ImG12 (ψ) is a generalization of the mean commutator (−i/2)h[X1 , X2 ]i one

This is a generalization of the well known Eberly-Wodkiewicz criterion for squeezed states. It however
is a relative criterion, since the "generalized mean commutator" |ImG12 (ψ)| may take, in general,
values from 0 to ∞. Another and stronger criterion for squeezed states is suggested by the observation

If the eigenstates of X1 + iX2 (or X1 − iX2 ) exist (canonical observables, spin and quasi-spin components e.t.c.), then ∆20 is equal to the minimal value of |ImGJφ (ψ)| within these eigenstates, and (13)
is rigorously valid [8]. If eigenstates of X1 ± iX2 do not exist, the critical quantity ∆0 should be estimated by different methods. The case of X1 = Jˆ and X2 = φ̂ is such a special case, since 2π–periodic
eigenfunctions of φ̂ ± iJˆ do not exist. Numerical considerations suggest that in this case ∆20 ≈ 0.5
(more precisely ≈ 0.49999), which is the minimal value that (∆φ)2 and (∆J)2 take simultaneously in
CS's |zi.
It turned out that both criterions (11) and (12) can be satisfied in many states from the families
{|z, ai} and {|zis }. Squeezing of ∆φ in |z, ai is not very strong, while in |zis it can be arbitrarily
strong.
Of course |zi are exact Heisenberg intelligent states for the Hermitian components X, Y of Z.
However neither ∆X nor ∆Y is in a satisfactory correspondence with the localization on a circle, as
one can easily check it on the example of cat states |z; ±i.
In conclusion we note that the above described scheme can be extended to represent correct
generalized UR's for several observables and (several) mixed states as well [4].
